content: Ok, I may be misunderstanding, but if you downloaded the messages, then both message folder items (e.g., INBOX, INBOX.msf ) should be copied to Mail\Local Folders, as they are no longer IMAP entities from within windows file explorer and then restart thunderbird. If you want the messages to be online, you can copy them in small groups, but that can be problematic as IMAP wasn't designed to work that way.

content:
re :This is a problem because there a several Parent folders and I have to open up each one of the in order to find in which Child Folder the mail went to.

When you have a load of nested foldered which are in a collapsed state then you are not going to know exactly which folder has mail mail until you click to open and drill down folders.

But you could use a much easier option.

  • Edit > Find > Search Messages
  • search for messages in: select the mail account name not a specific folder
  • Select : Search subfolders
  • Select : Match all of the following
  • 'Status' 'is' 'New'
  • click on 'Search'

Now you see every new mail. If you want to know which folder they are in then enable the column header 'Location' But you do not really want to do this every time you want to find new mail so do this:

  • click on 'Save as search folder'
  • Give it a suitable name like 'New mail'
  • Create as a subfolder of the actual mail account name so it becomes a top level folder.
  • Click on 'Create'

Now you will have a special saved search folder as a top level folder in the account. You do not select to save anything in this virtual type of folder. Whenever other folder indicate new mail or you just want to quickly check - use this 'New Mail' search folder.

From now onwards all new mail should be quickly visible via the search folder called 'New Mail' If you select another folder and read a new email then the search folder gets updated automatically to not include that email. If you select to read in the 'New Mail' folder then it's also not new mail in original folder.

This is how to get a quick view of what is new without ever needing to hunt it down. In the 'New Mail' folder you can easily enable the column header 'Location' to see which folder it is in.

Try it out, it's really a game changer.
creator: Toad-Hall

content: Message folders have two components, such as INBOX and INBOX.msf. The msf file is the index and the other is the mbox that contains the messages.

content: If you see a .msf file without an accompanying mbox file of the same name with no extension, it means the folder is set to not download message bodies (Account Settings, Sync. & Storage, Message Sync.).
creator: sfhowes

content:
Folders containing New emails marked blue and yellow star.

If auto filtered upon download to Inbox then they show up as new, blue and star no matter what folder they get auto filtered into.

But what is regarded as 'new': New means new since you last selected a folder.

Senario : you have new in Inbox - Inbox is blue, starred, so you select Inbox folder - emails that are new have star - maybe you decide not to read any emails meaning emails still have star at this point. Then you select another folder. The Inbox is no longer containing anything 'new' because nothing has been downloaded since you last selected Inbox.

Senario: This time when you select to run filter on Inbox - it filters all relevant emails in Inbox, but in addition a new mail arrived during the process because you have set the check emails every minute which is hardly any time since last check, so it downloaded and got moved instantly. You would not have seen that email in the Inbox. That would trigger the folder which got the new download to become blue with new.

Whilst you can set up Message filters to only filter upon manual selection, it is usual to also have it set up to do it automatically. I've got both selections set up in Message Filters as it does no harm.

If You have Message Filters automatically filtering upon download, then folders and emails get the 'new' flag; blue and star no matter what folder they get filtered into. But they only remain new and blue until you select the folder and stay in folder. You move away from folder then no longer new even if you did not read them.

When it comes to imap accounts, it may be worth checking to see if the folders are designed to auto check for new mail. Maybe you have new mail in folder but you would not know it because folder is not set up to auto check. Meaning when you select a folder it auto synchronises, downloaded new mail and shows this.

Right click on folder and select 'Properties' Is this checkbox selected : 'When getting new messages for this account, always check this folder'.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
First, check your SMTP server settings. It may be as simple as not having specified to use existing password for security. Click to 'account settings', scroll down left side until you see 'Outgoing servers SMTP' and click your smtp server. If if indicates no password, then click the 'edit' button and update the option to use password. That tells Thunderbird to use whatever password may already be stored in Thunderbird. Many email providers let this procedure with no password be used for years, but are now getting more sensitive to security. If you are unsure, please share a screenshot of the SMTP page or otherwise share the contents there.

If that isn't the issue, then you may need to contact your email provider to reset the password.
creator: davidsk
